channel.title: Book Review
channel.description: Find book reviews, essays, best-seller lists and news from The New York Times Book Review.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Debut Novels
item.description: New novels include Alix Hawley’s “All True Not a Lie in It,” a tongue-in-cheek fictional portrait of Daniel Boone.
item.author: By J.W. McCORMACK

item.title: Paperback Row
item.description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
item.author: By JOUMANA KHATIB

item.title: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
item.description: Michael Connelly continues to think up creative ways to keep his old war horse Harry Bosch on the job.
item.author: By MARILYN STASIO

item.title: Inside the List
item.description: Pat Conroy’s “A Lowcountry Heart,” a posthumous essay collection that includes some material from his charmingly capricious blog, is No. 11 on the hardcover nonfiction list.
item.author: By GREGORY COWLES

item.title: Caroline Leavitt’s New Novel Takes a Dark Departure
item.description: A teenage girl has a crush that goes frighteningly wrong in Caroline Leavitt’s “Cruel Beautiful World.”
item.author: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

item.title: A New Novel Stars Astronomer in the 1700s
item.description: John Pipkin’s “The Blind Astronomer’s Daughter” is a many-stranded tale of wide-eyed astronomers in the 1700s.
item.author: By KATHERINE A. POWERS

item.title: Letters to the Editor
item.description: Readers respond to recent reviews of Marie Ponsot’s “Collected Poems,” Gareth Stedman Jones’s “Karl Marx” and more.

item.title: Look It Up
item.description: John Simpson was hired by the Oxford English Dictionary when he was 22 years old. He became the O.E.D.’s chief editor.
item.author: By JENNIFER SZALAI

item.title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: John Grisham on ‘The Whistler’
item.description: This week, John Grisham talks about his latest novel, and Ben Macintyre discusses “Rogue Heroes.”

item.title: Megyn Kelly: By the Book
item.description: The Fox News anchor and author of “Settle for More” says “Bridget Jones’s Diary” reads “like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.”
